moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Be3
comment:
I like this rather unusual move and play it myself too. It's
idea - to prevent the quite unpleasant move Bf8-c5 with pressure on f2.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Be3 Nc5 10. Nc3 Nxb3 11. cxb3
comment:
If I'm not mistaken it's
Boleslavsky's idea. Of course it's a more common approach to take with a pawn
towards the centre, but here White has a concrete purpose: to exploit the
"backward" c7 pawn . To do this, White opens the c-file and tries to prevent
c7-c5. The next White goal: to exchange black-squared bishops and occupy black
square with pieces.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Be3 Nc5 10. Nc3 Nxb3 11. cxb3 Be7 12. Rc1 Qd7 13. h3
comment:
In the near future White's
knight will be better than Black's e6 bishop, so it's useful to prevent a
possible exchange.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Be3 Nc5 10. Nc3 Nxb3 11. cxb3 Be7 12. Rc1 Qd7 13. h3 O-O 14. Ne2 f6 15. exf6 Rxf6 16. Ned4 Nxd4 17. Bxd4 Rf5 18. Ne5 Qc8 19. Nc6 Bd6 20. Bc5
comment:
The c7 pawn stopped by two white pieces! Also the e6 bishop hasn't got any
outlets.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Be3 Nc5 10. Nc3 Nxb3 11. cxb3 Be7 12. Rc1 Qd7 13. h3 O-O 14. Ne2 f6 15. exf6 Rxf6 16. Ned4 Nxd4 17. Bxd4 Rf5 18. Ne5 Qc8 19. Nc6 Bd6 20. Bc5 Qd7 21. Bxd6 cxd6 22. Nd4 Re5 23. Rc3 b4 24. Rg3
comment:
It is redundant on the
c-file now, so the rook comes nearer to the opponent's king...

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. Be3 Nc5 10. Nc3 Nxb3 11. cxb3 Be7 12. Rc1 Qd7 13. h3 O-O 14. Ne2 f6 15. exf6 Rxf6 16. Ned4 Nxd4 17. comment:
Of course Black didn't want to weaken
his black squares more, but what else to do? After
